issues.description: The constructor parameter order in the solution does not follow the attribute order shown in the UML diagram in the problem statement. The problem explicitly instructs students to follow the UML order when implementing the constructor, but the solution's constructor signature places lectureName first and numberOfInscribedStudents second, while the UML lists numberOfInscribedStudents first and lectureName second. This mismatch can confuse students about the expected constructor parameter order and may cause test failures if automated checks expect the UML order.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor parameter order consistent with the UML in the problem statement, or update the UML/instructions to clearly state the intended parameter order. Concretely either (A) change the solution constructor to: Lecture(int numberOfInscribedStudents, String lectureName, int numberOfLecturers, int numberOfGuestStudents, int numberOfTutors) (matching the UML order shown), or (B) update the UML diagram and the textual instruction to list the attributes in the same order the solution currently uses (lectureName first). Ensure the template's constructor TODO and any tests align with the chosen order.

issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal inconsistency about attribute order: the prose list of attributes (used in the task description) orders attributes starting with lectureName, while the UML diagram orders them differently (numberOfInscribedStudents first, then lectureName). Because the text explicitly tells students to follow the UML order when creating the constructor, this contradiction is likely to confuse students about which order to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the discrepancy inside the problem statement: either reorder the prose attribute list to match the UML diagram or update the UML to match the prose. Also clarify in the constructor instruction which exact parameter order is expected (or explicitly state that any order is acceptable as long as all attributes are initialized), so students are not left uncertain.
